arguments.claim: s.10 taxes profits after deducting business outgoings but not capital expenditure; enumerated clauses not limit deductions

anchor.surface_text: The tax under the head Business is payable under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act. ... general scheme of the section is that profits or gains must be calculated after deducting outgoings reasonably attributable as business expenditure but so as not to deduct any portion of an expenditure of a capital nature.

arguments.claim: s.10(2) does not exhaustively deal with deductions; true profits require other deductions per Chitnavis (PC) accepted by SC

anchor.surface_text: If an expenditure comes within any of the enumerated classes of allowances, the case can be considered under the appropriate class but there may be an expenditure which, though not exactly covered by any of the enumerated classes, may have to be considered in finding out the true assessable profits or gains. This was laid down by the Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chitnavis

arguments.claim: Test for capital vs revenue: money laid out for enduring asset/investment (capital) or outgoing in doing business/current expense (revenue)

anchor.surface_text: To find out whether an expenditure is on the capital account or on revenue, one must consider the expenditure in relation to the business. ... The Questions to consider in this connection are for what was the money laid out? Was it to acquire an asset of an enduring nature for the benefit of the business, or was it an outgoing in the doing of the business?

arguments.claim: English Crown Spelter case illustrates capital investment (new company formation), distinguishable as not ordinary advance against goods

anchor.surface_text: In English Crown Spelter Co. Ltd v. Baker, the English Crown Spelter Co. carried on the business of zinc smelting ... It is impossible to look upon this as an ordinary business transaction of an advance against goods to be delivered

arguments.claim: Charles Marsden case: advance to secure long-term supply was capital venture to establish source, not deductible

anchor.surface_text: Charles Marsdon Sons. Ltd v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue ... Bowlatt, J. held this to be a capital expenditure not admissible as a deduction. He was of opinion that the payment was not an advance payment for goods

arguments.claim: Reids Brewery case: advances to customers in course of business (as bankers/moneylenders) deductible as revenue, not capital investment

anchor.surface_text: Reids Brewery Co. Ltd v. Nale. The Brewery Company there carried on ... business of bankers and money lenders making loans and advances to their customers. ... It was thus held to be a use of money in the course of the Companys business, and not an investment of capital at all.

holdings.text: the central point to decide is whether the money which was given up, represented a loss of capital, or must be treated as a revenue expenditure

anchor.surface_text: the central point to decide is whether the money which was given up, represented a loss of capital, or must be treated as a revenue expenditure. The tax under the head Business is payable under is. 10 of the Income-tax Act. That section provides by sub-s.  1  that the tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Profits and gains of business, etc. in respect of the profits or gains of any business, etc. carried on by him.

anchor.surface_text: If an expenditure comes within any of the enumerated classes of allowances, the case can be considered under the appropriate class but there may be an expenditure which, though not exactly covered by any of the enumerated classes, may have to be considered in finding out the true assessable profits or gains. holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Privy Council in Chitnavis and affirmed by SC; general provision s.10(1) allows deductions beyond enumerated s.10(2) clauses for true profits

holdings.text: The Questions to consider in this connection are for what was the money laid out? Was it to acquire an asset of an enduring nature for the benefit of the business, or was it an outgoing in the doing of the business?

anchor.surface_text: The Questions to consider in this connection are for what was the money laid out? Was it to acquire an asset of an enduring nature for the benefit of the business, or was it an outgoing in the doing of the business? If money be lost in the first circumstance, it is a loss of capital, but if lost in the second circumstance, it is a revenue loss.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established test for capital vs revenue: enduring asset/investment (capital) vs business outgoing/current expense (revenue)

holdings.text: Applying this test to this simple case, it is quite obvious which it is. The amount was an advance against price of one crop

anchor.surface_text: the central point to decide is whether the money which was given up, represented a loss of capital, or must be treated as a revenue expenditure. The tax under the head Business is payable under is. 10 of the Income-tax Act. That section provides by sub-s.  1  that the tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Profits and gains of business, etc. in respect of the profits or gains of any business, etc. carried on by him.

anchor.surface_text: If an expenditure comes within any of the enumerated classes of allowances, the case can be considered under the appropriate class but there may be an expenditure which, though not exactly covered by any of the enumerated classes, may have to be considered in finding out the true assessable profits or gains. This was laid down by the Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chitnavis

anchor.surface_text: The Questions to consider in this connection are for what was the money laid out? Was it to acquire an asset of an enduring nature for the benefit of the business, or was it an outgoing in the doing of the business? If money be lost in the first circumstance, it is a loss of capital, but if lost in the second circumstance, it is a revenue loss.

Applying this test to this simple case, it is quite obvious which it is. The amount was an advanced against price of one crop. The Oppigedars were to get the assistance number as an investment by the assessee companypany in its agriculture, but only as an advance payment of price.
